metadata.title: Boat Loan Interest & Bi-Weekly Payment Calculator (Advanced)
metadata.description: Calculate monthly or bi-weekly payments, total interest, and payoff time for boat loans. Supports standard monthly amortization, bi-weekly amortization (26 payments/year), and an accelerated bi-weekly option (bi-weekly = half of monthly payment). Includes accuracy notes and references to engineering and QA standards.

monthly_amortization.label: Standard monthly amortization
monthly_amortization.description: Compute the fixed monthly payment and totals using a standard amortizing loan formula with monthly compounding.

biweekly_annuity.label: Bi-weekly amortization (26 payments/year)
biweekly_annuity.description: Compute bi-weekly payments using 26 equal periods per year and standard annuity formula applied to the bi-weekly periodic rate.

accelerated_biweekly.label: Accelerated bi-weekly (half of monthly payment)
accelerated_biweekly.description: Estimate payoff time and interest when making bi-weekly payments equal to half the standard monthly payment. This typically results in 26 payments per year and accelerates payoff compared to 12 monthly payments.

n_month.label: Nominal monthly payments (for monthly payment calc)

monthly_payment_calc.label: Monthly payment used to derive accelerated bi-weekly

n_bi_to_payoff.label: Estimated number of bi-weekly payments to payoff

introduction: This calculator estimates payments, total interest, and payoff time for boat loans using either monthly amortization, bi-weekly amortization with 26 payments per year, or an accelerated bi-weekly approach where each payment equals half the monthly payment. Use the method that matches your lender or your intended payment plan.

Results are produced with standard amortization mathematics. Outputs are estimates intended for planning; actual lender calculations may differ due to rounding, payment timing, fees, or different compounding rules.
methodology: Monthly amortization uses the standard annuity formula with a monthly periodic rate (annual_rate / 12) and n = term_years * 12.
Bi-weekly annuity treats the loan as having 26 equal compounding periods per year and applies the annuity formula with periodic rate = annual_rate / 26 and n = term_years * 26.

Accelerated bi-weekly assumes each bi-weekly payment equals half of the standard monthly payment; because 26 bi-weekly payments produce the equivalent of 13 monthly payments per year, this typically shortens the term and lowers total interest. We estimate the required number of payments by solving the annuity formula for n.
how_is_calculated: Monthly payment formula: payment = P * r / (1 - (1 + r)^-n) where r = APR/12 and n = years*12.
Bi-weekly annuity: same formula with r = APR/26 and n = years*26.
Accelerated bi-weekly payoff estimate: derive monthly payment then set bi-weekly = monthly/2, solve n from payment = P * r_bi / (1 - (1 + r_bi)^-n) using logarithms, then compute totals.
examples: Example 1: $30,000 at 6% for 10 years. Monthly payment is calculated with r = 0.06/12 and n = 120. Bi-weekly annuity uses r = 0.06/26 and n = 260.

Example 2: If you make bi-weekly payments equal to half your monthly payment, you typically pay off the loan faster than the nominal term because you make the equivalent of 13 monthly payments per year instead of 12.

faqs.question: Why are bi-weekly payments sometimes cheaper overall?
faqs.answer: Making 26 bi-weekly payments (or making half-monthly payments twice per month plus the extra two payments per year) reduces principal faster and shortens the loan life, which lowers total interest compared with 12 monthly payments of the same nominal monthly amount.

faqs.question: Does this calculator include fees or taxes?
faqs.answer: No. This tool calculates principal and interest only. It does not include origination fees, title, taxes, insurance, or other charges. Add those separately when evaluating total cost.

faqs.question: Why might my lender's schedule differ?
faqs.answer: Lenders may use different compounding rules, day-count conventions, rounding, payment application order, or include fees. Always confirm with your lender for a definitive payoff schedule.

faqs.question: How precise are results?
faqs.answer: Results use floating-point arithmetic and closed-form formulas. They are suitable for planning but may differ from lender statements by small rounding tolerances. See accuracy notes and standards below.

glossary.definition: The process of paying off a loan through regular payments of principal and interest according to a schedule.
The interest rate applied to each payment period. For monthly, periodic rate = APR/12; for bi-weekly, periodic rate = APR/26.
A payment plan where bi-weekly payments equal half the monthly payment, resulting in 26 payments per year and typically faster payoff.
Annual Percentage Rate — the annual interest rate charged on the loan, expressed as a percentage.
